item.title: G-7 Leaders Seek ‘Resolution’ of Iranian Crisis in Statement
item.description: The Group of Seven leaders pushed for a de-escalation in the Middle East but didn’t call for an immediate end to the conflict between Israel and Iran in a statement that also affirmed Israel’s right to defend itself.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: (L/R) European Council President António Costa, Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba, Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, French President Emmanuel Macron, Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney, US President Donald Trump, British Prime Minister Keir Starmer, German Chancellor Friedrich Merz and European Union President Ursula von der Leyen pose for a family photo during the Group of Seven (G7) Summit at the Kananaskis Country Golf Course in Kananaskis, Alberta, Canada on June 16, 2025. (Photo by Brendan SMIALOWSKI / AFP) (Photo by BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Trump Leaves G-7 Summit Early as Israel-Iran Tension Spikes
item.description: President Donald Trump’s hasty exit from the Group of Seven conference in Canada deepened questions about his promise to bring peace to an increasingly violent world and added fresh evidence of his skepticism toward the institutions that have long underpinned US diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump at the G-7 Summit on June 16.

item.title: Britain's Housing Splurge Is Long Overdue
item.description: The Labour government’s plan to boost spending on affordable homes has the potential to pay for itself in wider economic benefits.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Brooker

media:content.media:description: ASHFORD, KENT - JULY 11: Construction work takes place on a short-term pod housing project for the homeless at Henwood Industrial Estate on July 11, 2024 in Ashford, Kent. The project, in which 23 pods will provide temporary accommodation to people facing homelessness, is scheduled to be completed in September with its first residents moving in soon thereafter. The project was spearheaded by Ashford Borough Council with additional funding coming from the national government. (Photo by Chris J Ratcliffe/Getty Images)

item.title: Australian PM’s Meeting With Trump Scrapped After G-7 Departure
item.description: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese’s first in-person meeting with Donald Trump was canceled after the president decided to leave a Group of Seven summit early to focus on the conflict between Israel and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Michael Heath

media:content.media:description: Anthony Albanese Photographer: Hilary Wardhaugh/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Set to Depart G-7 Early as Israel-Iran Tension Spikes
item.description: President Donald Trump is set to depart the Group of Seven leaders’ summit in Canada a day early, after warning residents of Tehran to evacuate the city as Israel continued to bombard Iran in a bid to disable its nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Stephanie Lai, Arsalan Shahla, Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: Canada's Prime Minister Mark Carney speaks during a meeting with US President Donald Trump on the sidelines of the G7 Summit, in Kananaskis, Canada, on June 16. Photographer: Mark Schiefelbein/AP Photo

item.title: Trump, Ishiba Fail to Reach Trade Deal at G-7 Summit
item.description: US President Donald Trump and Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba failed to reach an agreement on a trade package on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit, an outcome that leaves the Asian nation inching closer to a possible recession as the pain of US tariffs hits its economy.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami, Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba at the Group of Seven (G7) Summit in Kananaskis, Alberta, Canada, on June 16.

item.title: China Warns Iran-Israel Conflict May Spiral, Calls for Peace
item.description: China warned the Iran-Israel conflict may spread wider instability in the Middle East, with Foreign Minister Wang Yi reaching out to both countries as their days-old conflict shows no end in sight.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao

media:content.media:description: Wang Yi Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

item.title: US Defeats Teachers Unions’ Suit to Restore Columbia Funding
item.description: The Trump administration won dismissal of a lawsuit by two unions seeking to stop the withholding of $400 million in federal funds from Columbia University, saying the groups didn’t have the legal right to challenge the decision.
item.dc:creator: Chris Dolmetsch

media:content.media:description: Columbia University. 2960 Broadway corner of 116th Street, New York, Manhattan, USA. This private university, one of the oldest in the city, is among the best in the world, especially in the field of medical and scientific research. The campus was built in 1897, and today thousands of students annually passing through their classrooms. From here have come 49 Nobel laureates, a figure which not all universities can claim. The esplanade of the campus is a quiet place where students roam and which highlights the ancient LIBRARY Low Library, which is accessed via a wide staircase which lies the statue of Alma Mater.. (Photo by: Sergi Reboredo/VW Pics/Universal Images Group via Getty Images)

item.title: OpenAI Snags $200 Million Contract With US Defense Department
item.description: OpenAI has won a $200 million contract for a pilot program aimed at helping the US Defense Department determine how it could use artificial intelligence for a range of administrative and security tasks.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Metz

item.title: Brazil Congress Threatens to Deal Fresh Blow to Lula Fiscal Plan
item.description: President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva’s efforts to shore up Brazil’s budget are on the brink of another setback after Congress advanced a push to block tax increases on some financial transactions from taking effect.
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias, Martha Viotti Beck

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva

item.title: What’s New in the Senate Version of Trump’s Tax and Spending Bill
item.description: Senate Republicans plan to modify President Donald Trump’s massive fiscal package to lower maximum deductions for state and local taxes and limit the impact of a “revenge” tax on foreign investors.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol at dawn in Washington.

item.title: Wind, Solar Credits Set to End Early in Senate GOP Tax Bill
item.description: Senate Republicans released a bill that would end tax credits for wind and solar earlier than for other sources, and make only modest changes to most other incentives, dashing hopes of those seeking relief from major cuts passed by the House.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: Contractors install SunRun solar panels on the roof of a home in San Jose, California, U.S., on Monday, Feb. 7, 2022. California regulators are delaying a vote on a controversial proposal to slash incentives for home solar systems as they consider revamping the measure.

item.title: Trump to Leave G-7 Summit and Return to Washington on Monday
item.description: President Donald Trump is cutting short his visit to the Group of Seven leaders’ summit, according to the White House, and returning to Washington.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump during the G7 Summit in Canada on June 16. Photographer: Suzanne Plunkett/Pool/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: US Approves Sale of $2 Billion in Military Hardware to Australia
item.description: The US State Department has signed off on the potential sale of military hardware to Australia valued at an estimated $2 billion (A$3.1 billion), including fighter jet spare parts.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: A US Navy Super Hornet fighter jet.

item.title: Senate Republican Tax Bill Would End Federal Taxes on Many Guns, Silencers
item.description: Senate Republicans’ tax bill would eliminate federal taxes and regulations on short-barreled rifles, short-barreled shotguns and silencers as well as preempt state or local licensing requirements in a win for gun-rights advocates.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis, Chris Cioffi

media:content.media:description: A visitors pulls the slide of a pistol with a silencer at a gun displays at a National Rifle Association outdoor sports trade show on February 10, 2017 in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. (Photo by DOMINICK REUTER / AFP) (Photo by DOMINICK REUTER/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Senate Republicans Release Revised Tax Cuts and Debt Limit Bill
item.description: Senate Republicans propose to cut trillions of dollars in taxes for households and businesses in their version of President Donald Trump’s signature economic package, a plan that comes at the expense of curbing health coverage for some low-income Americans and adding to US deficits.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, April 3, 2025. Senate Republicans on Wednesday unveiled a budget blueprint designed to fast-track a renewal of President Donald Trump's tax cuts and an increase to the nation's borrowing limit, ahead of a planned vote on the resolution later this week. Photographer: Daniel Heuer/Bloomberg

item.title: Senate Republicans Propose More Aggressive Medicaid Cuts to Help Pay for Tax Bill
item.description: Senate Republicans are proposing cuts to the Medicaid program for low-income and disabled people that are more aggressive than policies the House passed to help pay for President Donald Trump’s sweeping tax package.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Cohrs Zhang

media:content.media:description: A healthcare professional in the ICU at Van Wert County Hospital in Van Wert, Ohio.

item.title: Trump Tax Bill to Boost Biden’s Semiconductor Tax Credit to 30%
item.description: The Senate’s draft tax bill calls for temporarily increasing an investment credit for semiconductor manufacturers, enhancing a subsidy for chipmakers to build factories in the US.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Diaz

media:content.media:description: A bare wafer stacker sorts silicon wafers in Building 51 at Micron Technology Inc. headquarters in Boise, Idaho, US, on Monday, June 10, 2024. The US announced in April its plans to award Micron Technology Inc. $6.1 billion in grants and as much as $7.5 billion in loans to help the memory-chip maker build new American factories, rounding out a slew of major federal awards for advanced semiconductor manufacturing.

item.title: Minnesota Shooting Suspect Faces US Charges Including Murder
item.description: US prosecutors charged alleged shooter Vance Boelter with two counts of murder in the deaths of Minnesota State Representative Melissa Hortman and her husband, in what officials referred to as a “murderous rampage” on Saturday morning.
item.dc:creator: Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: Vance L. Boelter

item.title: Rich Colleges Would Face Lower Tax Hike Under Senate Bill
item.description: Wealthy US colleges scored a win on Monday with the release of Senate Republicans’ tax bill, which would institute a lower tax increase on endowments than what GOP House members have backed.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Albright

media:content.media:description: The Baker Library of the Harvard Business School on the Harvard University campus in Boston, Massachusetts, US, on Tuesday, May 27, 2025. President Donald Trump on Monday threatened to divert billions in grant dollars away from Harvard University and give those funds to trade schools across the US, escalating his clash with the elite institution.

item.title: US Won’t Back G-7’s Iran De-Escalation Push in Sign of Disunity
item.description: The US is blocking a proposed Group of Seven statement urging Israel and Iran to de-escalate their conflict, people familiar with the matter said, highlighting the distance that’s opened up between President Donald Trump and other members of the bloc.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Alberto Nardelli

item.title: Senate Delays and Scales Back ‘Revenge Tax’ in Trump Bill
item.description: Senate Republicans plan to delay and make less onerous a levy targeting foreign companies and investors from countries that the US determines have been unfairly taxing US companies.

item.title: Trump Says Russia Sanctions Would Cost US ‘a Lot of Money’
item.description: US President Donald Trump indicated at the Group of Seven summit that he is in no rush to impose tougher sanctions on Russia, dismissing pressure from allied leaders eager to do more to push Moscow to the negotiating table.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

item.title: RFK Jr.’s Policy Moves Are Weakening Vaccine Infrastructure, Fired Advisers Say
item.description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s decision to overhaul a key committee on vaccine policy has left the country’s vaccine infrastructure “critically weakened,” former members of the group said in a piece published in JAMA on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Damian Garde, Michelle Amponsah

media:content.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., US secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), during a Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 14, 2025. The FDA and NIH are pushing out a joint research initiative that will explore nutrition issues and infant dietary exposures, fueling Kennedy's agenda to scrutinize the food supply.

item.title: Stocks Rise as Fear of All-Out Mideast War Eases: Markets Wrap
item.description: Relative calm returned to global markets, with stocks climbing and oil sinking alongside gold as fears subsided that Israel’s war against Iran would escalate into a wider conflict. News reports that Tehran wants to restart talks over its nuclear program also fueled risk-on sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

item.title: Israel to Continue Strikes Despite Reports Iran Seeks Talks
item.description: Israel will pursue its military operations against Iran regardless of the progress of any potential negotiations involving the US, Israeli Strategic Affairs Minister Ron Dermer said in an interview on Bloomberg Television.
